item.title: [WFCORE-405] Filesystem deployment scanner for a managed domain
item.description:
Is there any folder or path at which if any .war is put, in such a way that when JBOSS AS 7.1.0 start in domain mode the .war file deploy in Master node and it's related slave Node.

For Example......... In standalone mode if we put .war file in /jboss-as-7.1.0.Final/standalone/deployments/ folder and start the JBOSS AS 7.1.0 in standalone mode ,the .war deploy properly.......i want same thing domain mode, in other-server-group .....

Means the requirement is that the .war file should put in one folder and when JBOSS AS 7.1.0 start in domain mode the .war file should deploy in other-server-group .............

status.description: This issue was once resolved, but the resolution was deemed incorrect. From here issues are either marked assigned or resolved.

comments.comment: Hitesh, questions like these are meant to be asked in the user forums here https://community.jboss.org/community/jbossas7?view=discussions. Please create a new thread there with the relevant details. I'm closing this JIRA.

This is a valid feature request, just phrased as a question. So I'm reopening, and I'll edit it a bit.

Please note that my reopening this is not a promise to implement it. But it's a valid request.

I changed the JIRA title, the relevant components, and removed the references to "clustering" from the description. The term "clustering" is overloaded and typically implies the AS's HA features, which are orthogonal to managed domains and server groups. This feature would be about managed domains and server groups; the fact that those things are useful for managing HA clusters is a side effect.

Doing this would involve a thread under the control of a Host Controller scanning a filesystem location and invoking commands to update the domain-wide configuration. This has a couple implications:

1) The scanner could not be part of a subsystem, as it is in a standalone server. A Host Controller does not install runtime services for subsystems. It only tracks their configuration in order to provide that configuration to the servers under its control.

This would mean elevating the scanner notion into the core AS, which is a concern.

2) Only the master Host Controller would be able to be configured with such a scanner. Only the master is allowed to make updates to the domain wide configuration.

The basic implementation difference between such a scanner and the one currently used for standalone servers is the addition of configurations for which server-groups should be affected by the scanner. The list of management operations generated by the scanner would then need to include the relevant server-group-level operations. This would add a fair amount of complexity, particularly around some of the edge cases, such as the user adding a new server-group to the scanner's config when the HC is not running – this would require detecting the need to add the relevant deployments to the new server group upon boot. Much more problematic is the case where a user removes a server group from the scanner's config when the HC is not running.

Similar issues exist regarding interaction between this scanner and other administrative clients, such as the web based admin console. What happens if an admin using the console removes a scanner-controlled deployment from a particular server-group?

I had a customer which wanted this feature and thought I would comment on it:

Can't it be a subsystem and those hot-deployments be placed in the DC node? Actually I think it makes more sense than putting it in one of the HC (since DC is the one which replicates the binaries and where the deployment repository is centralized).

If the hot-deployment folder would synchronize with deployment repository (instead of being the repository as in standalone), this would solve the problem of removing/detecting new deployments (as current it already works with normal deployments)?

Also about the configuration, it would be ideal if we could configure in the server-group itself which hot-deployment folders it "listens" to (although I don't see how that would be possible, maybe an ${} expression in the subsystem and a server-group-level properties property?)

About configuration, I believe it would be better for this "subsystem" to read
